title: Doctors ready to announce results of study into links between serious brain disease and former professional footballers
text:
Landmark research into the prevalence of serious brain disease among former professional footballers will be published on Monday, almost 18 years after the death from dementia of Jeff Astle.

The 22-month study by the Glasgow Brain Injury Research Group followed The Daily Telegraph’s campaign for answers over the incidence of neurological disease among former footballers amid the anecdotal evidence of many ex-players developing dementia.

The Telegraph had reported how, at the time of the 50-year anniversary of winning the World Cup in 1966, half of England’s surviving outfield players were suffering from dementia or memory loss, as well as past warnings that were directed to both the Football Association and the Professional Footballers’ Association which dated back to the 1990s.

The new research has been funded by the FA and PFA and follows a previous study by the two football bodies that was launched shortly before an inquest in 2002 ruled that Astle had died from an ‘industrial disease’ caused by repetitive blows to the head.

A subsequent post-mortem confirmed that he had suffered from chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) - a specific type of dementia which is associated with repeated head trauma.
